Chief Complaint: hypoxemic resp failure and hypotension
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note above, including assessment and plan.
   HPI:
   50M h/o metastatic renal CA s/p nephrectomy, IL-2, mini-allograft SCT,
   DLI x 2 last in [**12-8**], emphysema/pulmonary fibrosis on home 02 presents
   with sepsis. Started on NIPPV, hydrocortisone, broad spectrum abx at
   OSH yesterday. TTE at OSH EF 65-70, LVH, PASP 54, RV dilation.
   Intubated en route. On FiO2 100% 7.02/104/105. Had received vecuronium.
   ECG with deep TW inversions. Hypotensive here, received 4L NS. Vent
   transitioned to PCV. Started on norepinephrine and subsequently
   vasopressin.

   Troponin-T:168/15/0.34, ALT / AST:44/52, Alk Phos / T Bili:95/0.9,
   Differential-Neuts:67.0 %, Band:2.0 %, Lymph:18.0 %, Mono:9.0 %,

   Ca++:6.1 mg/dL, Mg++:2.0 mg/dL, PO4:4.3 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   50 yo man with metastatic renal cell CA s/p allo- SCT with subsequent
   severe chronic resp failure thought to be emphysema and fibrosis and
   possible GVHD/BOOP (CT from last spring demonstrates severe cystic and
   fibrotic changes with almost no normal appearing lung) presented with 2
   wk prodrome, now with catastrophic acute on chronic failure. CXR shows
   diffuse opacification. Severe septic shock, now on 2 pressors. Not
   recently on corticosteroids.
   SEPTIC SHOCK
   Most likely source pneumonia. R/O for influenza at OSH.
   Vanc/Zosyn/Levoflox/Bactrim/Caspofungin/acyclovir prophylaxis.
   Cx pending.
   Markers pending.
   Not safe for bronch.
   RESP FAILURE
   Infection, sepsis, acute exacerbation of underlying chronic disease as
   well as cardiac component with likely severe PH and also likely
   impaired LV filling and impaired LV outflow with subsequent CHF.
   - oxygenation currently adequate on high PEEP, max FiO2
   - consider paralysis if we are unable to decrease FiO2
   - rescue strategy may include inhaled prostacyclin or NO, though he may
   have severe F/Q mismatch/shunt given his underlying severe lung
   disease.
   HYPOTENSION
   Septic shock. Has one adrenal gland with metastatic lesion.
   Fluid resuscitation. Received high dose steroids at OSH. Add high dose
   hydrocortisone.
   CARDIAC
   Severe PH. New TW inversions, likely demand ischemia with tachy,
   hypotension.
   TTE.
   Aspirin.
   SEDATION with fent 350 /versed 6
   COLD FOOT- observe for now
   other issues per Dr[**Name (NI) 2079**] note.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2120-4-15**] 09:10 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2120-4-15**] 11:24 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2120-4-16**] 12:14 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: Mouth care
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition :ICU
   Total time spent: 80 minutes
   Patient is critically ill
   ------ Protected Section ------
   Met with pt
s wife, [**Name (NI) 1288**], and explained septic shock, cardiogenic
   shock with severe PH, RV failure. Described the echocardiogram
   findings. Explained severity of his condition, on maximal vent support
   and high doses of 2 pressor agents, as well as receiving very broad
   antimicrobial coverage. Answered questions.
   30 minutes.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) 2010**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], MD
   on:[**2120-4-16**] 19:00 ------

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 50-year-old man with metastatic renal cell carcinoma who has undergone allogenic stem cell transplantation (allo-SCT) and is presenting with severe chronic respiratory failure, thought to be due to emphysema and pulmonary fibrosis, as well as possible graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) or bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP).

The patient has developed septic shock, likely due to pneumonia, and is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics. He is also experiencing respiratory failure, which is likely due to a combination of infection, sepsis, and acute exacerbation of underlying chronic disease, as well as cardiac component with likely severe pulmonary hypertension (PH) and impaired left ventricular (LV) filling and outflow.

The patient's hypotension is attributed to septic shock, and he has received high-dose steroids at the outside hospital. He is also receiving hydrocortisone in the ICU.

The patient has a history of metastatic disease to his adrenal gland, which may impact his response to stress and sepsis.

The patient's cardiac status is also concerning, with new T-wave inversions on the electrocardiogram (ECG), likely indicating demand ischemia with tachycardia and hypotension. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) has been ordered to further evaluate his cardiac function.

The patient is receiving sedation with fentanyl and midazolam, and his cold feet are being observed. He is also receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management in the ICU. His code status is full code, and his disposition is to remain in the ICU.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Sepsis and septic shock: The patient is already experiencing septic shock, and further deterioration can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's underlying chronic respiratory disease and acute exacerbation may lead to further respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is concerning, with new T-wave inversions and possible demand ischemia. Further cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest, can occur.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's history of metastatic disease to his adrenal gland may impact his response to stress and sepsis, leading to adrenal insufficiency.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's underlying chronic respiratory disease and sepsis may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Renal failure: The patient's underlying kidney disease and sepsis may lead to further renal failure.
7. Infections: The patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, but further infections can still occur, particularly in the respiratory and urinary tracts.

Close monitoring and management in the ICU are essential to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 50-year-old male with metastatic renal cell carcinoma, who underwent allogenic stem cell transplantation (allo-SCT) and is now experiencing severe chronic respiratory failure, thought to be due to emphysema and pulmonary fibrosis, possibly complicated by graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) or bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP).

The patient was admitted with a 2-week prodrome and presented with catastrophic acute on chronic respiratory failure, septic shock, and hypotension. He has severe septic shock, requiring two pressors, and is not recently on corticosteroids.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with severe chronic respiratory failure, acute exacerbation of underlying chronic disease, and cardiac component with likely severe pulmonary hypertension (PH) and impaired left ventricular (LV) filling and outflow with subsequent congestive heart failure (CHF).

The patient's cardiovascular status is also critical, with severe PH, new T-wave inversions, and likely demand ischemia with tachycardia and hypotension.

The patient has several potential medical complications that can arise, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require mechanical ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) to maintain adequate oxygenation.
2. Sepsis: The patient has severe septic shock, which can lead to multiple organ dysfunction and death if not promptly treated.
3. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac status is critical, and he may require vasopressors and inotropes to maintain adequate cardiac output.
4. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's severe PH can lead to right ventricular failure and death if not managed promptly.
5. Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD): The patient's allo-SCT may have led to GVHD, which can cause significant morbidity and mortality.
6. Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing secondary infections, particularly pneumonia, which can be life-threatening.
7. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid status is critical, and he may require fluid resuscitation or diuresis to maintain adequate perfusion.
8. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can lead to organ dysfunction and death if not promptly treated.

The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of severe sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction. The patient's condition has been stable over the past 24 hours, with continued support from mechanical ventilation and vasopressors. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37C, heart rate of 70 bpm, and blood pressure of 84/58 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 96% on 60% FiO2.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of sepsis, with an elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and lactate level. The patient's liver function tests are mildly elevated, and the patient's creatinine level is within normal limits.

The patient's imaging studies show evidence of pulmonary edema and bilateral pleural effusions.

The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic kidney disease.

The patient's allergies include Flagyl (oral) and rash.

The patient's medications include vasopressin, cisatracurium, midazolam, norepinephrine, fentanyl, famotidine, and heparin.

The patient's family has been informed of the gravity of their situation and has been involved in the decision-making process.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis is likely to cause further organ dysfunction, including renal, hepatic, and respiratory failure.
2. Pulmonary edema: The patient's pulmonary edema can worsen, leading to respiratory failure and the need for further mechanical ventilation.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac status is unstable, and cardiac arrhythmias can occur, including tachycardia, bradycardia, and cardiac arrest.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient's coagulopathy can worsen, leading to bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding and intracranial hemorrhage.
5. Infection-related complications: The patient's sepsis can lead to secondary infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's malnutrition can worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and increased risk of complications.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's gastrointestinal status is unstable, and complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and obstruction can occur.
8. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and further deterioration can occur, leading to the need for renal replacement therapy.
9. Hepatic failure: The patient's liver function is compromised, and further deterioration can occur, leading to the need for liver transplantation.
10. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiovascular status is unstable, and complications such as cardiac arrest, myocardial infarction, and cardiac failure can occur.

   50M h/o metastatic renal CA s/p nephrectomy, IL-2, mini-allograft SCT,
   DLI x 2 last in [**12-8**], emphysema/pulmonary fibrosis on home 02 presents
   with sepsis.
   # Sepsis: Likely pneumonia given new opacities on CXR, although
   difficult to read due to fibrosis. No other apparent localizing
   symptoms. Ruled-out for flu at OSH. Urine, GI sources less probable.
   Given immunocompromise from malignancy, at risk for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) 1156**], etc.
   Progression of GVHD could be contributing.
   - IVF resuscitation for MAP>65, IVF aggressively then pressors if
   necessary
   - Vanc, zosyn, levofloxacin, bactrim, caspofungin to cover broadly for
   now given critical illness
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures
   - Legionella antigen, glucan, galactomannan
   - CT chest and possible bronch when more stable
   - Follow WBC count, fever curve
   - PPD to be read [**4-17**]
   # Respiratory failure: Pneumonia in patient with poor pulmonary reserve
   due to emphysema, GVHD, fibrosis. Avoid high pressures given fibrotic
   lungs, will attempt pressure control to limit.
   - Continue mechanical ventilatory support, wean as tolerated
   # Acidosis: Primary respiratory, non-gap, lactate normal. Increase
   minute ventilation. [**Month (only) 60**] require paralysis for adequate ventilation.
   # Hypotension: Likely sepsis, although probably component of
   hypovolemia as well. At risk for PE given malignancy. GI bleed unlikely
   as Hct stable. Adrenal insufficiency possible.
   - Treat broadly per above
   - [**Last Name (un) **] stim in AM, after high dose steroids from OSH are off.
   - LENIs for ? DVT.  Don't want to empirically start heparin given RCC
   and risk to bleed.
   - Guaiac stools, HCT has been stable.
   # Cardiac: Patient with probable demand ischemia in setting of
   hypotension, tachycardia, and sepsis; less likely unstable plaque.
   - Continue to trend enzymes and treat underlying cause
   - ASA, hold on beta-blocker and statin
   - TTE to eval for wall motion abnormality
   - Repeat ECG in am
   # Metastatic renal CA: Recurrent disease s/p donor lymphocyte
   transplant [**12-8**].
   - BMT to follow
   - Avoid steroids given risk to graft
   - Continue acyclovir ppx for now, will discuss with BMT
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Replete (Full) - [**2120-4-17**] 06:20 AM 40 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

* The patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma, who has undergone nephrectomy, IL-2 therapy, mini-allograft stem cell transplant, and donor lymphocyte infusion (DLI). He presents with sepsis, likely pneumonia, and is at risk for PCP and other opportunistic infections due to his immunocompromised state.
* The patient has respiratory failure due to pneumonia, emphysema, GVHD, and pulmonary fibrosis, and is receiving mechanical ventilatory support.
* He has acidosis, primarily respiratory in origin, and is at risk for hypotension, which is likely due to sepsis, hypovolemia, and adrenal insufficiency.
* The patient has cardiac issues, including probable demand ischemia, and is at risk for pulmonary embolism (PE) due to his malignancy.
* He has a history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma, which is recurrent despite donor lymphocyte infusion.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Sepsis-related organ failure, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute kidney injury (AKI), and cardiac arrest.
* Pneumonia progression, leading to respiratory failure and potential need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
* Opportunistic infections, such as PCP, cytomegalovirus (CMV), and herpes simplex virus (HSV), which can lead to pneumonia, encephalitis, and other life-threatening complications.
* Cardiac complications, including myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest, due to demand ischemia and potential underlying coronary artery disease.
* Pulmonary embolism, which can lead to respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, and death.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and death.
* Adrenal insufficiency, which can lead to hypotension, shock, and death.
* Metastatic disease progression, which can lead to further organ failure and death.

To manage these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals, as well as supportive care, including mechanical ventilatory support, vasopressors, and fluid resuscitation. Additionally, the patient's underlying conditions, such as emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, and GVHD, require ongoing management and optimization.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma, who has undergone nephrectomy, IL-2 therapy, mini-allograft stem cell transplant, and donor lymphocyte infusion. He is currently admitted to the ICU with sepsis, hypoxic respiratory failure, and hypotension. He has a poor pulmonary reserve due to emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, and possible graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). He is also at risk for opportunistic infections, including Pneumocystis carinii (PCP) and Legionella.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.2C (100.8F)
* Heart rate: 70 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 84/58 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 34 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Central venous pressure: 26 mmHg

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.1 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 11.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 119 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* LDH: 856 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.3 mg/dL

The patient is being treated with:

* Vasopressin
* Cisatracurium
* Midazolam
* Fentanyl
* Piperacillin-tazobactam
* Vancomycin
* Levofloxacin
* Bactrim
* Acyclovir
* Hydrocortisone
* IV steroids

Potential medical complications:

* Sepsis and septic shock
* Respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Cardiac arrest and cardiogenic shock
* Renal failure and acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)
* Opportunistic infections, including Pneumocystis carinii (PCP) and Legionella
* Adrenal insufficiency
* Pulmonary embolism (PE)
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)

Assessment and plan:

* The patient is at high risk for sepsis and septic shock, and will be treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
* The patient's respiratory failure will be managed with mechanical ventilation and pressure control ventilation.
* The patient's hypotension will be treated with vasopressors and fluids.
* The patient's cardiac status will be monitored closely, and treatment will be directed at managing his cardiac output and blood pressure.
* The patient's renal function will be closely monitored, and treatment will be directed at managing his creatinine levels and preventing AKI.
* The patient's GVHD will be closely monitored, and treatment will be directed at managing his symptoms and preventing further complications.
* The patient's opportunistic infections will be closely monitored, and treatment will be directed at managing his symptoms and preventing further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with metastatic renal cancer, who has undergone nephrectomy, IL-2, mini-allograft stem cell transplant, and donor lymphocyte infusion. He presents to the ICU with sepsis, hypotension, and hypoxia. He has a history of emphysema and pulmonary fibrosis, which may be contributing to his respiratory failure. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with high levels of PEEP. His blood pressure is being supported with vasopressors, and he is receiving antibiotics to cover for possible pneumonia and PCP.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk for further deterioration due to his underlying lung disease and sepsis.
2. Sepsis: The patient is septic, and his condition is likely to worsen if not properly managed.
3. Pneumonia: The patient has a high risk of developing pneumonia due to his immunocompromised state and respiratory failure.
4. PCP: The patient is at risk for PCP due to his immunocompromised state and respiratory failure.
5. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient has a history of adrenalectomy and is at risk for adrenal insufficiency.
6. Cardiac compromise: The patient has a history of cardiac disease and is at risk for cardiac compromise due to his hypotension and tachycardia.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding due to his anticoagulation therapy and underlying liver disease.
8. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis due to his immobility and underlying cancer.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory status with mechanical ventilation and high levels of PEEP.
2. Continue to treat the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and vasopressors as needed.
3. Consider performing a bronchoscopy to obtain a deep ET sputum sample for culture.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider performing an echocardiogram to assess for cardiac compromise.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and consider performing a gastrointestinal bleed screen.
6. Consider performing a CT chest to assess for pulmonary embolism.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's white blood cell count and fever curve to assess for sepsis.
8. Consider performing a stress test to assess for cardiac compromise.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma, who has undergone nephrectomy, IL-2 therapy, mini-allograft stem cell transplantation, and donor lymphocyte infusion. He is currently in the ICU due to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and hypotension.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6C, heart rate of 67 bpm, blood pressure of 117/60 mmHg, respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. He is intubated and sedated, with a PEEP of 14 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, with a WBC count of 13.1 x 10^9/L, and elevated troponin-T levels, with a value of 0.22 ng/mL. His blood cultures are pending, and his urine legionella antigen test is negative.

The patient's chest X-ray shows possible opacities, and his CT chest is pending. He is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and levofloxacin, to cover for possible PCP and other infections.

The patient's respiratory status is improving, with a decrease in PEEP and FiO2, and he is tolerating pressure control ventilation. However, he is still requiring two pressors to maintain his blood pressure.

The patient's cardiac status is complex, with probable demand ischemia, tachycardia, and sepsis. He is being treated with dobutamine, and his cardiac output is improving.

The patient's metastatic renal cell carcinoma is being treated with donor lymphocyte infusion, and his BMT is pending.

The patient's ICU care includes nutrition support, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP. He is being closely monitored for signs of infection, sepsis, and cardiac complications.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient is already in septic shock, and further deterioration can occur if not properly managed.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's chest X-ray shows possible opacities, and he is at risk for developing pneumonia.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is complex, and further deterioration can occur if not properly managed.
4. Metastatic disease progression: The patient's metastatic renal cell carcinoma is being treated with donor lymphocyte infusion, and further progression can occur if not properly managed.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient is at risk for gastrointestinal complications, including ileus, constipation, and diarrhea.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but further deterioration can occur if not properly managed.
7. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with metastatic renal cell carcinoma, who underwent nephrectomy, IL-2 therapy, mini-allograft stem cell transplant, and donor lymphocyte infusion (DLI) 12 days ago. He presented to the emergency department with sepsis, hypoxic respiratory failure, and hypotension. He was intubated and admitted to the ICU due to severe septic shock. The patient has a history of emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, and is at risk for Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP) and other opportunistic infections due to his immunocompromised state.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: intubated, sedated, and mechanically ventilated with PEEP of 14 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%.
* Cardiovascular status: hypotensive, requiring vasopressors, with a CI of 1.8 and a decrease in SV variability indicating minimal fluid responsiveness.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: using a Vigileo device for non-invasive monitoring.
* Infections: septic shock, likely due to pneumonia, with negative urine legionella antigen and no growth on cultures to date.
* Metabolic status: hyperglycemic, with an ISS prn regimen.
* Gastrointestinal status: tolerating total parenteral nutrition (TF) with low residuals.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: due to pneumonia, emphysema, and pulmonary fibrosis.
2. Hypotension: likely due to sepsis, hypovolemia, and adrenal insufficiency.
3. Sepsis: with a high risk of progression to septic shock and multi-organ failure.
4. Opportunistic infections: such as PCP, due to the patient's immunocompromised state.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: due to the patient's history of emphysema and pulmonary fibrosis.
6. Cardiac complications: due to the patient's history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma and potential demand ischemia.
7. Hemodynamic instability: due to the patient's tenuous cardiovascular status and potential fluid responsiveness.

Plan:

1. Continue mechanical ventilatory support and wean FiO2 as tolerated.
2. Monitor and manage hypotension with vasopressors and fluids as needed.
3. Treat sepsis with broad-spectrum antibiotics and consider bronchoscopy for culture data.
4. Monitor and manage infections, including PCP and other opportunistic infections.
5. Continue total parenteral nutrition and advance as tolerated.
6. Monitor and manage metabolic status, including glycemic control.
7. Consider placement of a PA catheter for more accurate hemodynamic monitoring.
8. Continue to communicate with the patient's family and readdress code status as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with metastatic renal cell carcinoma who has undergone nephrectomy, IL-2 treatment, mini-allograft stem cell transplant, and donor lymphocyte infusion. He presents to the ICU with sepsis, hypoxic respiratory failure, and hypotension. He is intubated and receiving pressors to maintain blood pressure. The patient has a history of emphysema and pulmonary fibrosis, which may be contributing to his respiratory failure.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6C (97.9F)
* Heart rate: 67 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 117/60 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 34 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.1 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 11.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 119 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.22 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.7 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* LDH: 274 IU/L

The patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover possible pneumonia, legionella, and PCP. He is also receiving steroids for PCP and adrenal insufficiency.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure and possible opacities on CXR suggest pneumonia, which is a common complication in immunocompromised patients.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock, leukocytosis, and fevers indicate a high risk of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to pneumonia, emphysema, and pulmonary fibrosis, which can lead to hypoxia and respiratory arrest.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia, hypotension, and possible demand ischemia suggest cardiac instability, which can lead to arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac arrest.
5. Metastatic renal cell carcinoma: The patient's recurrent disease may progress, leading to further complications and poor outcomes.
6. Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD): The patient's immunocompromise and history of mini-allograft stem cell transplant increase his risk of GVHD, which can lead to skin, gastrointestinal, and hepatic complications.
7. Infection: The patient's immunocompromise and presence of central lines and catheters increase his risk of infection, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover possible pneumonia, legionella, and PCP.
2. Monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory status closely.
3. Consider placing a PA catheter to monitor the patient's hemodynamics.
4. Continue steroids for PCP and adrenal insufficiency.
5. Consider bronchoscopy to obtain a deep ET sputum culture.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely, considering echocardiography and cardiac enzymes.
7. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and titrate PEEP and FiO2 as tolerated.
8. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and consider total parenteral nutrition if necessary.
9. Consider stress ulcer prophylaxis and VAP prevention measures.
10. Continue to communicate with the patient's family and readdress code status today.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma, who underwent nephrectomy, IL-2 therapy, mini-allograft stem cell transplantation, and donor lymphocyte infusion. He presents with sepsis, hypoxic respiratory failure, and tenuous respiratory status.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's hypoxia and possible opacities on CXR suggest a high likelihood of pneumonia. The patient's immunocompromised state due to malignancy and GVHD increases the risk of opportunistic infections.
2. PCP: The patient is at risk for PCP due to his immunocompromised state and the presence of fibrosis in his lungs.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure is likely due to pneumonia and his underlying pulmonary fibrosis and emphysema.
4. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension, tachycardia, and fever suggest sepsis, which is likely caused by pneumonia and/or other infections.
5. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's history of adrenalectomy and metastasis to the remaining adrenal gland increases the risk of adrenal insufficiency.
6. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to sepsis, hypovolemia, and/or adrenal insufficiency.
7. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension suggest cardiac complications, including demand ischemia, which may be exacerbated by his sepsis and hypovolemia.
8. DVT: The patient is at risk for DVT due to his malignancy and immobility.
9. GI bleed: The patient's Hct is stable, but he is at risk for GI bleed due to his malignancy and sepsis.
10. Infections: The patient is at risk for a wide range of infections due to his immunocompromised state and the presence of central lines and other invasive devices.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover PCP and other infections.
2. Mechanical ventilatory support to manage respiratory failure.
3. Dobutamine infusion to increase cardiac output and blood pressure.
4. Vasopressin and levophed to support blood pressure.
5. IV hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency.
6. Prophylactic anticoagulation to prevent DVT.
7. Monitoring for GI bleed and other complications.
8. Serial laboratory tests to monitor for infection and other complications.
9. Consideration of bronchoscopy and CT chest to further evaluate the patient's respiratory status.
10. Follow-up with the patient's oncologist to discuss further management of his metastatic renal cell carcinoma.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma, who has undergone nephrectomy, IL-2 therapy, mini-allograft stem cell transplant, and donor lymphocyte infusion. He presents to the ICU with sepsis, hypotension, and hypoxic respiratory failure. He has a history of emphysema and pulmonary fibrosis, which may be contributing to his respiratory failure. He is also at risk for opportunistic infections, including Pneumocystis carinii (PCP) due to his immunocompromised state.

Assessment:

The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and he requires high levels of PEEP to maintain oxygenation. He has a high risk of developing pneumonia, and his CXR is difficult to read due to fibrosis. He has been treated with antibiotics to cover for PCP and other broad-spectrum infections. His cardiac status is also concerning, with probable demand ischemia and possible adrenal insufficiency.

Plan:

* Continue to manage his respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and pressure control ventilation to avoid high pressures.
* Wean FiO2 as tolerated and consider bronchoscopy when more stable.
* Treat his sepsis with antibiotics and consider additional therapies such as corticosteroids and antifungals.
* Monitor his cardiac status closely and consider placement of a PA catheter for more accurate hemodynamic monitoring.
* Consider treatment for PCP and other opportunistic infections.
* Continue to manage his pain and sedation with fentanyl and midazolam.

Potential medical complications:

* Pneumonia: The patient is at high risk for developing pneumonia due to his immunocompromised state and respiratory failure.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac status is concerning, and he may be at risk for cardiac arrest due to his hypotension, tachycardia, and sepsis.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient may have adrenal insufficiency due to his history of adrenalectomy and metastatic disease.
* Opportunistic infections: The patient is at risk for developing opportunistic infections such as PCP, cytomegalovirus (CMV), and herpes simplex virus (HSV).
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and he may be at risk for further respiratory failure due to his underlying lung disease and sepsis.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
* Consider placement of a PA catheter for more accurate hemodynamic monitoring.
* Treat the patient's sepsis aggressively with antibiotics and other therapies as needed.
* Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and consider treatment for PCP and other opportunistic infections.
* Continue to manage the patient's pain and sedation with fentanyl and midazolam.
* Consider referral to a pulmonologist or critical care specialist for further management of the patient's respiratory failure.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma, who has undergone nephrectomy, IL-2 therapy, mini-allograft stem cell transplant, and donor lymphocyte infusion. He presented to the hospital with hypoxic respiratory failure, fevers, and hypotension.

The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. He has been diagnosed with sepsis, pneumonia, and cardiogenic shock. He has also been found to have pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular failure.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.4C
* Heart rate: 74 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 142/70 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 34 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 12.3 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 98 g/L
* Platelet count: 124 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 22 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: sodium 145 mmol/L, potassium 4.2 mmol/L, chloride 113 mmol/L

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Metastatic renal cell carcinoma
* Pulmonary fibrosis
* Emphysema
* Hypertension
* Chronic kidney disease
* Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
* Pulmonary hypertension
* Right ventricular failure
* Sepsis
* Pneumonia
* Cardiogenic shock

The patient's medications include:

* Dobutamine
* Midazolam
* Fentanyl
* Captopril
* Hydrocortisone
* Acyclovir
* Famotidine
* Heparin
* ASA
* ACEI

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for sepsis
* Continue mechanical ventilation for respiratory failure
* Wean dobutamine and captopril as tolerated
* Monitor UOP and CI
* Consider diuresis if UOP tapers off
* Continue IV hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency
* Wean IV hydrocortisone over the next few days
* Monitor for signs of PE and adjust therapy accordingly
* Consider diuresis if UOP tapers off
* Continue to monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust therapy accordingly

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Cardiogenic shock
* Sepsis
* Pneumonia
* Pulmonary hypertension
* Right ventricular failure
* Adrenal insufficiency
* Chronic kidney disease
* Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
* Hypertension

The patient's family has been informed of his condition and code status has been discussed. The patient is currently in the ICU and will be monitored closely for any changes in his condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of metastatic renal cancer, who has undergone nephrectomy, IL-2 therapy, mini-allograft stem cell transplant, and donor lymphocyte infusion (DLI). He is currently intubated and ventilated in the ICU due to hypoxic respiratory failure, fevers, and hypotension. He has a history of emphysema and pulmonary fibrosis, which is likely contributing to his respiratory failure. He also has evidence of cutaneous graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and is at risk for opportunistic infections such as Pneumocystis carinii (PCP).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4C, heart rate of 74 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 142/70 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 96% on 50% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2). His white blood cell count is 12.3 x 10^9/L, and his platelet count is 124 x 10^9/L.

The patient has undergone various interventions, including intubation, mechanical ventilation, and administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics. He has also received corticosteroids for suspected PCP and adrenal insufficiency.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to pneumonia, which is complicated by his underlying emphysema and pulmonary fibrosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to a combination of factors, including his underlying malignancy, immunocompromise, and pneumonia.
3. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac failure is likely due to his underlying pulmonary hypertension, which is secondary to his pulmonary fibrosis.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding is likely due to his underlying malignancy and immunocompromise.
5. Opportunistic infections: The patient is at risk for opportunistic infections such as PCP, which is a common complication of immunocompromise.
6. Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD): The patient's GVHD is likely contributing to his respiratory failure and may require further treatment.
7. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency is likely due to his underlying malignancy and may require further treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for pneumonia and sepsis.
2. Administer corticosteroids for suspected PCP and adrenal insufficiency.
3. Consider bronchoscopy for further evaluation of respiratory failure.
4. Continue dobutamine for cardiac failure.
5. Consider diuresis for further management of cardiac failure.
6. Continue ACEI for afterload reduction.
7. Monitor for signs of opportunistic infections such as PCP.
8. Consider prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer.
9. Continue TPN for nutritional support.
10. Monitor the patient's wife and family for any concerns or questions.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient's presentation with hypotension, fevers, and leukocytosis is concerning for sepsis. The patient is already on broad-spectrum antibiotics, and cultures have been sent.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's hypoxia and possible opacities on CXR suggest pneumonia. The patient is already on antibiotics, but the diagnosis is not yet confirmed.
3. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's PAH and RV failure on ECHO, along with the need for dobutamine and captopril, suggest cardiogenic shock. The patient's cardiac output is decreased, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to a mixed picture of septic shock, cardiogenic shock, and possible adrenal insufficiency. The patient's blood pressure is still labile, and further monitoring is necessary.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is due to pneumonia, emphysema, and possible GVHD. The patient is already on pressure control ventilation, and further adjustments may be necessary.
6. Infection: The patient's fever curve and WBC count are decreasing, but the patient is still at risk for further infection. The patient's antibiotics should be continued, and cultures should be monitored.
7. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's history of metastasis to one adrenal gland and the need for IV hydrocortisone suggest adrenal insufficiency. The patient's steroid dose should be weaned carefully.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's guaiac stools and high residuals suggest a risk of gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's anticoagulation status should be monitored.
9. Catheter-related bloodstream infection: The patient has multiple central lines and an arterial line, which increases the risk of catheter-related bloodstream infection. The patient's lines should be monitored regularly.
10. Venous thromboembolism: The patient is at risk for venous thromboembolism due to immobility and the presence of central lines. The patient should receive prophylactic anticoagulation.

The patient's plan of care should focus on managing these potential complications, including:

* Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics for sepsis and pneumonia
* Adjusting ventilator settings to optimize respiratory function
* Monitoring and managing cardiac output and blood pressure
* Weaning steroids and adjusting anticoagulation status
* Monitoring for gastrointestinal bleeding and catheter-related bloodstream infection
* Providing prophylactic anticoagulation for venous thromboembolism
* Following up with the patient's wife and family to ensure they are informed of the patient's condition.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications:

**Patient Information**

* 50-year-old male with metastatic renal cancer, previously treated with nephrectomy, IL-2, mini-allograft stem cell transplant, and donor lymphocyte infusion (DLI)
* Currently intubated and sedated in the ICU due to hypoxic respiratory failure, fevers, and hypotension
* Has a history of emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
* Immunocompromised due to malignancy and recent transplant

**Current Status**

* Respiratory failure: pneumonia likely, possibly due to GVHD, fibrosis, and poor pulmonary reserve
* Hypotension: likely a mixed picture, with septic shock initially, but now possibly due to low cardiac output and pulmonary hypertension
* Cardiac: probable demand ischemia, tachycardia, and sepsis; less likely unstable plaque
* Metastatic renal cancer: recurrent disease after DLI

**Potential Medical Complications**

* Sepsis: patient is at high risk due to immunocompromise and pneumonia
* Pneumonia: likely due to GVHD, fibrosis, and poor pulmonary reserve
* Respiratory failure: patient may require prolonged mechanical ventilation and may have difficulty weaning from ventilator
* Cardiac complications: patient may have low cardiac output due to pulmonary hypertension, and may require inotropes and vasopressors
* Metastatic renal cancer: patient is at risk for recurrent disease and may require further treatment
* Gastrointestinal complications: patient may have ileus due to sepsis and may require treatment with lactulose and oral naloxone
* Venous thromboembolism (VTE): patient is at risk due to immobility and may require prophylaxis with heparin and compression stockings
* Stress ulcer: patient may require treatment with ranitidine and may be at risk for bleeding due to immunocompromise and anticoagulation therapy

**Treatment Plan**

* Continue antimicrobial therapy for pneumonia and sepsis
* Maintain mechanical ventilation and titrate sedation as needed
* Continue dobutamine and vasopressors to support cardiac function
* Consider ACEI for afterload reduction and diuresis if UOP tapers off
* Monitor for signs of GVHD and treat accordingly
* Continue immunosuppressive therapy as per transplant protocol
* Consider bronchoscopy and CT chest when patient is more stable
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and treat accordingly
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and treat accordingly

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 50-year-old male with a history of metastatic renal cancer, presented to the emergency department with hypoxic respiratory failure, fevers, and hypotension. He was intubated due to hypoxic respiratory failure and hypotensive requiring pressors. The patient has been treated with antibiotics for presumed pneumonia, including vancomycin, zosyn, levofloxacin, and bactrim.

The patient's respiratory status has been improving, with decreased need for oxygen and increased tolerance of decreased PEEP and FiO2. However, he remains on pressure control mode with normalization of ABG. Overnight, the patient had mucous plugging with suctioning of thick sputum, requiring increased sedation and transiently becoming dysynchronous.

The patient's cardiovascular status has been complex, with likely mixed causes of hypotension, including septic shock, pulmonary hypertension, and RV hypokinesis. He has been treated with dobutamine, and his cardiac output has improved. He is currently on low-dose ACEI for afterload reduction and IV hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of sepsis, with elevated WBC count, CRP, and lactate. His liver function tests are elevated, and his renal function is stable. He has been treated with antimicrobial agents, including vancomycin and zosyn, and is currently on IV steroids for PCP and adrenal insufficiency.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains fragile, and he may require further adjustment of his ventilator settings to optimize oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypotension is likely to be a complex issue, and further optimization of his cardiovascular status may be necessary to prevent further decline.
3. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock may persist, and he may require further treatment with antimicrobial agents and vasopressors to control his infection.
4. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's pulmonary hypertension may worsen, leading to further right ventricular dysfunction and decreased cardiac output.
5. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency may require further treatment with IV hydrocortisone to prevent further decline.
6. Infection: The patient's infection may progress, leading to further organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Metastatic disease: The patient's metastatic renal cancer may progress, leading to further systemic symptoms and potentially life-threatening complications.

Based on this information, I recommend further monitoring of the patient's respiratory, cardiovascular, and metabolic status, as well as ongoing treatment with antimicrobial agents and vasopressors to control his infection and hypotension.

   hypotension made a septic shock picture predominate, however after
   adequate fluid rescusitation pt continued to require 2 pressors.  His
   TTE and vigileo monitoring were consistent with low cardiac output due
   to pt
s severe pulmonary hypertension due to pulmonary fibrosis and
   subsequent RV hypokinesis, a non-fluid responsive state.  Dobutamine
   challenge resulted in increased CO to normal range with ability to be
   weaned off both levophed and vasopressin and addition of captopril
   which led to decreased afterload allowed decrease in dobutamine.  Also,
   initial concern for adrenal insufficiency as patient has one adrenal
   gland with a metastasis, though he does not clinically appear to be
   functionally adrenally insufficient at this point.  UOP remains high at
   ~100-200cc/hour.
   - Continue dobutamine
   - Continue HD monitoring with Vigileo device
   - Treat broadly for infection per above
   - IV hydrocort Q6 for adrenal insufficiency, will start wean today with
   50mg q12, and subsequent wean over next few days.
   - Initially concerned for PE, however have more likley explanations for
   hypotension as listed above, LENIs negative
   - Guaiac stools, HCT has been stable.
   # Metastatic renal CA: Recurrent disease s/p donor lymphocyte
   transplant [**12-8**].

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma, who underwent nephrectomy, IL-2 therapy, mini-allograft stem cell transplant, and donor lymphocyte infusion. He presented to the hospital with hypoxic respiratory failure, fevers, and hypotension.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia is likely the source of respiratory failure and sepsis, given his poor pulmonary reserve due to emphysema, possible graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), and fibrosis.
* Septic shock: The patient was initially hypotensive, hypoxic, and febrile, with a high white blood cell count. He was intubated due to hypoxic respiratory failure and hypotension requiring pressors. Legionella urine antigen was negative, and all other cultures have no growth to date. He is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, zosyn, and levofloxacin.
* Cardiogenic shock: The patient has pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and right ventricular failure, as evidenced by echocardiogram. He was started on dobutamine, which improved his cardiac index and pressures. Captopril was added for afterload reduction, allowing for a decrease in dobutamine.
* Cardiac: The patient has probable demand ischemia in the setting of hypotension, tachycardia, and sepsis, with less likelihood of unstable plaque.
* Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely a mixed picture, initially presenting as septic shock, but later found to be due to low cardiac output caused by severe pulmonary hypertension and subsequent right ventricular hypokinesis. Dobutamine challenge resulted in increased cardiac output, and captopril was added to decrease afterload.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for further respiratory complications, including pneumonia, given his underlying pulmonary disease and immunocompromised state.
2. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to his broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy and potential for further infections.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient is at risk for cardiac complications, including cardiogenic shock, due to his underlying cardiac disease and pulmonary hypertension.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient has a history of adrenal metastasis, and his current treatment with hydrocortisone may not be adequate to prevent adrenal insufficiency.
5. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, and he is at risk for bleeding complications, particularly with his current treatment with anticoagulants.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of gastrointestinal disease, including emphysema and pulmonary fibrosis, may increase his risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding, perforation, or obstruction.
7. Renal complications: The patient's underlying renal disease and potential for further complications, such as acute kidney injury, may increase his risk for renal failure.

In summary, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, septic shock, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac complications. He is at risk for further complications, including pneumonia, sepsis, cardiac complications, adrenal insufficiency, bleeding, gastrointestinal complications, and renal complications. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

* Glucose: 98 mg/dL
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.7 mmol/L
* Calcium: 8.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.8 mg/dL

The patient's radiology results show:

* Chest X-ray: shows diffuse interstitial thickening consistent with pulmonary fibrosis, and a small right pleural effusion.

The patient's plan is to continue broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, levofloxacin, and bactrim, pending the results of cultures. He will also continue to receive hydrocortisone and methadone. The patient's sedation regimen will be continued, with a goal of adequate sedation while minimizing respiratory depression.

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Nutrition: replete with fiber
* Glycemic control: strict insulin therapy
* Lines: multi-lumen and arterial lines
* Prophylaxis: DVT prophylaxis with heparin, stress ulcer prophylaxis with famotidine, and VAP prophylaxis with chlorhexidine.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

* Respiratory failure: continued need for mechanical ventilation, respiratory acidosis, and hypoxemia
* Sepsis: progression to septic shock, multi-organ dysfunction, and death
* Hypotension: continued need for vasopressors, cardiac arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest
* Metastatic renal cell carcinoma: progression of disease, new metastases, and death
* Graft-versus-host disease: progression of GVHD, liver dysfunction, and death
* Pulmonary fibrosis: progression of fibrosis, respiratory failure, and death
* Infection: progression of infection, sepsis, and death.

   DLI x 2 last in [**12-8**], emphysema/pulmonary fibrosis on home 02
   presented to OSH with hypoxic respiratory failure, fevers and
   hypotension.
   # Septic shock: On presentation to OSH pt hypotensive, hypoxic with
   fevers and leukocytosis. On arrival to [**Hospital1 54**] ICU was intubated due to
   hypoxic respiratory failure and hypotensive requiring pressors.  Likely
   pneumonia given hypoxia and possible opacities on CXR, although
   difficult to read due to fibrosis. No other apparent localizing
   symptoms. Ruled-out for flu at OSH.  At this point, WBC and fever curve
   decreasing. Covered on broad spectrum antibiotics.
   - Legionella urine ag negative, all other cultures no growth to date.
   - Vanc, zosyn, levofloxacin, bactrim IV for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] to cover
   broadly given critical illness.  As patient was on bactrim prophylaxis
   for PCP as outpatient and not on steroids, risk for PCP very low;
   therefore, will dc high dose bactrim and restart ppx dose.
   - D/C [**Name10 (NameIs) **] sun if cultures negative
   - Also on IV steroids for PCP and adrenal insufficiency, see below
   - Glucan, galactomannan  pending
   - Follow WBC count, fever curve, decreasing
   - PPD negative
   - Continue acyclovir ppx, vanc/zosyn/levoflox
   # Respiratory failure: Pneumonia in patient with poor pulmonary reserve
   due to emphysema, ?GVHD, fibrosis.
   Pt tolerated decrease in PEEP and Fi02 yesterday.  Attempted to switch
   to A/C, however pt less sedated off pressors and pulling large TV
   (~1600), dysynchronous with vent.
   - Back on pressure control for now, based on transpulmonary pressure
   (10 and -2), will titrate down FiO2 as tolerated today.   Can consider
   changing to PSV or SIMV with low set respiratory rate if tolerated.
   -Off cisatracurium since [**4-17**].  Currently sedated on midazolam and
   fentanyl on maximal doses.  Will try trial of methadone to help
   decrease versed/fentanyl doses today. Attempt wean as tolerated. Can
   consider propofol in addition in order to lower doses of
   versed/fentanyl.
   # Cardiogenic shock: Patient found to have PAH and RV failure on ECHO.
   Started on dobutamine with improvement in CI as well as pressures.
   Also started on captopril for afterload reduction which enabled
   decrease in dobutamine with continued improvement in hemodynamics.
   - Wean dobutamine today
   - Continue to monitor UOP and CI. If UOP decreases, will consider lasix
   drip if patient becomes very positive

   hypotension, tachycardia, and sepsis; less likely unstable plaque.
   - CE
s trended down,  have stopped following.
   - ASA
   - ACEI as above for afterload reduction
   - Consider diuresis if UOP tapers off to further decrease preload.
   # Hypotension: Improved. Likely a mixed picture. Initially pt
   presentation of acute hypoxia with leukocytosis and fevers with
   hypotension made a septic shock picture predominate, however after
   adequate fluid rescusitation pt continued to require 2 pressors.  His
   TTE and vigileo monitoring were consistent with low cardiac output due
   to pt
s severe pulmonary hypertension due to pulmonary fibrosis and
   subsequent RV hypokinesis, a non-fluid responsive state.  Dobutamine
   challenge resulted in increased CO to normal range with ability to be
   weaned off both levophed and vasopressin and addition of captopril
   which led to decreased afterload allowed decrease in dobutamine.  Also,
   initial concern for adrenal insufficiency as patient has one adrenal
   gland with a metastasis, though he does not clinically appear to be
   functionally adrenally insufficient at this point.  UOP remains high at
   ~100-200cc/hour.
   - Continue dobutamine
   - Continue HD monitoring with Vigileo device
   - Treat broadly for infection per above
   - IV hydrocort Q6 for adrenal insufficiency, will start wean today with
   50mg q12, and subsequent wean over next few days.
   - Initially concerned for PE, however have more likley explanations for
   hypotension as listed above, LENIs negative
   - Guaiac stools, HCT has been stable.
   # Metastatic renal CA: Recurrent disease s/p donor lymphocyte
   transplant [**12-8**].

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma, who presented to the hospital with hypoxic respiratory failure, fevers, and hypotension. He was intubated and received broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected pneumonia. The patient has been on various medications, including vasopressors, steroids, and antifungals. His current condition is complicated by septic shock, respiratory failure, cardiogenic shock, and hypotension.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's condition is complicated by septic shock, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised due to pneumonia, emphysema, and pulmonary fibrosis, which can lead to further respiratory decline.
3. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac output is compromised due to pulmonary hypertension, RV failure, and hypotension, which can lead to further cardiac decline.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to a mixed picture of septic shock, cardiogenic shock, and hypovolemia, which can lead to further organ dysfunction.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for further infections, particularly pneumonia, due to his compromised immune system and respiratory status.
6. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma and the presence of a single adrenal gland with a metastasis raise concerns about adrenal insufficiency, which can lead to further hypotension and organ dysfunction.
7. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of pulmonary fibrosis and RV failure raises concerns about pulmonary embolism, which can lead to further respiratory decline and cardiac compromise.

The patient's treatment plan includes ongoing broad-spectrum antibiotics, vasopressors, and antifungals, as well as close monitoring of his respiratory, cardiac, and hemodynamic status. The patient's condition is complex and requires ongoing evaluation and management by the ICU team.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7C, heart rate of 52 beats per minute, blood pressure of 119/51 mmHg, respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93%. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus bradycardia.

The patient's fluid balance is being closely monitored, with a total intake of 5,654 mL and a total output of 3,280 mL. The patient's urine output is 3,280 mL, and the patient is receiving fluids through multiple lines, including a multi-lumen line and an arterial line.

The patient's lab results show mild anemia with a hemoglobin level of 10.4 g/dL and a white blood cell count of 13.5. The patient's liver enzymes are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase level of 31 and an alanine aminotransferase level of 57. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

The patient's arterial blood gas results show a pH of 7.46, a partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 36 mmHg, and a partial pressure of oxygen of 176 mmHg.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's current condition include:

1. Infection: The patient's history of antibiotic use and the presence of a central line and arterial line increase the risk of infection.

4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's blood pressure is slightly low, and their heart rate is slightly elevated, which may indicate cardiovascular instability.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is not well-documented, but the patient's history of antibiotic use and the presence of a central line and arterial line increase the risk of neurological complications.

Based on this information, it is recommended that the patient's condition be closely monitored, and that the healthcare team be prepared to address any potential complications that may arise.

   SINGLE SEMI-UPRIGHT VIEW OF THE CHEST AT APPROXIMATELY 7 a.m.: This

   Lung volumes remain low and widespread interstitial thickening is

   with diffuse fibrosis. A slight relative increase in air space opacity
   at the
   right lung base (most evident when in comparison to the scout film from

   torso of [**2120-2-13**]) is largely unchanged, as is a small right pleural

   50M h/o metastatic renal CA s/p nephrectomy, IL-2, mini-allograft SCT,

   presented to OSH with hypoxic respiratory failure, fevers and
   hypotension.
   # Septic shock: On presentation to OSH pt hypotensive, hypoxic with
   fevers and leukocytosis. On arrival to [**Hospital1 54**] ICU was intubated due to
   hypoxic respiratory failure and hypotensive requiring pressors.  Likely
   pneumonia given hypoxia and possible opacities on CXR, although
   difficult to read due to fibrosis. No other apparent localizing
   symptoms. Ruled-out for flu at OSH.  At this point, WBC and fever curve
   decreasing. Covered on broad spectrum antibiotics.
   - Legionella urine ag negative, all other cultures no growth to date.
   - Vanc, zosyn, levofloxacin, bactrim IV for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] to cover
   broadly given critical illness.  As patient was on bactrim prophylaxis
   for PCP as outpatient and not on steroids, risk for PCP very low;
   therefore, will dc high dose bactrim and restart ppx dose.
   - D/C [**Name10 (NameIs) **] sun if cultures negative
   - Also on IV steroids for PCP and adrenal insufficiency, see below
   - Glucan, galactomannan  pending

   - PPD negative
   - Continue acyclovir ppx, vanc/zosyn/levoflox
   # Respiratory failure: Pneumonia in patient with poor pulmonary reserve
   due to emphysema, ?GVHD, fibrosis.
   Pt tolerated decrease in PEEP and Fi02 yesterday.  Attempted to switch
   to A/C, however pt less sedated off pressors and pulling large TV
   (~1600), dysynchronous with vent.
   - Back on pressure control for now, based on transpulmonary pressure
   (10 and -2), will titrate down FiO2 as tolerated today.   Can consider
   changing to PSV or SIMV with low set respiratory rate if tolerated.
   -Off cisatracurium since [**4-17**].  Currently sedated on midazolam and

   decrease versed/fentanyl doses today. Attempt wean as tolerated. Can

   versed/fentanyl.
   # Cardiogenic shock: Patient found to have PAH and RV failure on ECHO.
   Started on dobutamine with improvement in CI as well as pressures.
   Also started on captopril for afterload reduction which enabled
   decrease in dobutamine with continued improvement in hemodynamics.

   - Continue to monitor UOP and CI. If UOP decreases, will consider lasix

s trended down,  have stopped following.

   SINGLE SEMI-UPRIGHT VIEW OF THE CHEST AT APPROXIMATELY 7 a.m.: This
   exam is
   largely unchanged from the prior exam. Endotracheal tube, nasogastric
   tube,
   feeding tube, and right internal jugular catheter are all in unchanged
   positions. Again, the feeding tube terminates above the GE junction.
   Lung volumes remain low and widespread interstitial thickening is
   consistent
   with diffuse fibrosis. A slight relative increase in air space opacity
   at the
   right lung base (most evident when in comparison to the scout film from
   the CT
   torso of [**2120-2-13**]) is largely unchanged, as is a small right pleural
   effusion.
   Assessment and Plan
   50M h/o metastatic renal CA s/p nephrectomy, IL-2, mini-allograft SCT,
   DLI x 2 last in [**12-8**], emphysema/pulmonary fibrosis on home 02
   presented to OSH with hypoxic respiratory failure, fevers and
   hypotension.
   # Septic shock: On presentation to OSH pt hypotensive, hypoxic with
   fevers and leukocytosis. On arrival to [**Hospital1 54**] ICU was intubated due to
   hypoxic respiratory failure and hypotensive requiring pressors.  Likely
   pneumonia given hypoxia and possible opacities on CXR, although
   difficult to read due to fibrosis. No other apparent localizing
   symptoms. Ruled-out for flu at OSH.  At this point, WBC and fever curve
   decreasing. Covered on broad spectrum antibiotics.
   - Legionella urine ag negative, all other cultures no growth to date.
   - Vanc, zosyn, levofloxacin, bactrim IV for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] to cover
   broadly given critical illness.  As patient was on bactrim prophylaxis
   for PCP as outpatient and not on steroids, risk for PCP very low;
   therefore, will dc high dose bactrim and restart ppx dose.
   - D/C [**Name10 (NameIs) **] sun if cultures negative
   - Also on IV steroids for PCP and adrenal insufficiency, see below
   - Glucan, galactomannan  pending
   - Follow WBC count, fever curve, decreasing
   - PPD negative
   - Continue acyclovir ppx, vanc/zosyn/levoflox
   # Respiratory failure: Pneumonia in patient with poor pulmonary reserve
   due to emphysema, ?GVHD, fibrosis.
   Pt tolerated decrease in PEEP and Fi02 yesterday.  Attempted to switch
   to A/C, however pt less sedated off pressors and pulling large TV
   (~1600), dysynchronous with vent.
   - Back on pressure control for now, based on transpulmonary pressure
   (10 and -2), will titrate down FiO2 as tolerated today.   Can consider
   changing to PSV or SIMV with low set respiratory rate if tolerated.
   -Off cisatracurium since [**4-17**].  Currently sedated on midazolam and
   fentanyl on maximal doses.  Will try trial of methadone to help
   decrease versed/fentanyl doses today. Attempt wean as tolerated. Can
   consider propofol in addition in order to lower doses of
   versed/fentanyl.
   # Cardiogenic shock: Patient found to have PAH and RV failure on ECHO.
   Started on dobutamine with improvement in CI as well as pressures.
   Also started on captopril for afterload reduction which enabled
   decrease in dobutamine with continued improvement in hemodynamics.
   - Wean dobutamine today
   - Continue to monitor UOP and CI. If UOP decreases, will consider lasix
   drip if patient becomes very positive
   # Cardiac: Patient with probable demand ischemia in setting of
   hypotension, tachycardia, and sepsis; less likely unstable plaque.
   - CE
s trended down,  have stopped following.
   - ASA
   - ACEI as above for afterload reduction
   - Consider diuresis if UOP tapers off to further decrease preload.
   # Hypotension: Improved. Likely a mixed picture. Initially pt
   presentation of acute hypoxia with leukocytosis and fevers with
   hypotension made a septic shock picture predominate, however after
   adequate fluid rescusitation pt continued to require 2 pressors.  His
   TTE and vigileo monitoring were consistent with low cardiac output due
   to pt
s severe pulmonary hypertension due to pulmonary fibrosis and
   subsequent RV hypokinesis, a non-fluid responsive state.  Dobutamine
   challenge resulted in increased CO to normal range with ability to be
   weaned off both levophed and vasopressin and addition of captopril
   which led to decreased afterload allowed decrease in dobutamine.  Also,
   initial concern for adrenal insufficiency as patient has one adrenal
   gland with a metastasis, though he does not clinically appear to be
   functionally adrenally insufficient at this point.  UOP remains high at
   ~100-200cc/hour.
   - Continue dobutamine
   - Continue HD monitoring with Vigileo device
   - Treat broadly for infection per above
   - IV hydrocort Q6 for adrenal insufficiency, will start wean today with
   50mg q12, and subsequent wean over next few days.
   - Initially concerned for PE, however have more likley explanations for
   hypotension as listed above, LENIs negative
   - Guaiac stools, HCT has been stable.
   # Metastatic renal CA: Recurrent disease s/p donor lymphocyte
   transplant [**12-8**].
   - BMT to follow
   - Continue acyclovir ppx for now, will discuss with BMT
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma, who presented to the emergency department with hypoxic respiratory failure, fevers, and hypotension. He was intubated and admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of septic shock. He has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and has had a mixed response. His cardiac function is compromised due to pulmonary hypertension and RV failure. He has been started on dobutamine and captopril to improve cardiac output and reduce afterload. His hypotension is likely due to a combination of factors, including septic shock, low cardiac output, and pulmonary hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to pneumonia, which is a common complication in patients with underlying lung disease. He may require further treatment with antibiotics and mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac function is compromised due to pulmonary hypertension and RV failure. He may require further treatment with medications to improve cardiac output and reduce afterload.
3. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is likely due to a combination of factors, including pneumonia, bacteremia, and adrenal insufficiency. He may require further treatment with antibiotics and supportive care.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency is likely due to his history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma and the use of corticosteroids. He may require further treatment with corticosteroids and supportive care.
5. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's hypotension is likely due to a combination of factors, including septic shock, low cardiac output, and pulmonary hypertension. He may require further treatment with anticoagulation therapy and supportive care.
6. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised due to his underlying disease and the use of nephrotoxic medications. He may require further treatment with dialysis and supportive care.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and supportive care for the patient's respiratory failure and septic shock.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust his medications as necessary to improve cardiac output and reduce afterload.
3. Monitor the patient's adrenal function and adjust his corticosteroid therapy as necessary to prevent adrenal insufficiency.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his medications as necessary to prevent renal failure.
5. Consider further treatment with anticoagulation therapy and supportive care for the patient's pulmonary embolism.
6. Consider further treatment with dialysis and supportive care for the patient's renal failure.

Recommendations:

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with renal cell carcinoma, admitted to the ICU with severe respiratory failure, cardiogenic/septic shock, and RV hypoplasia. He has been weaned off dobutamine and stress dose steroids. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, sedation, and antibiotics. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1C, heart rate of 67 bpm, and blood pressure of 133/60 mmHg. His respiratory support includes a PCV+ ventilator mode with a pressure of 28 cmH2O, respiratory rate of 30, and FiO2 of 50%.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure remains a concern, and the healthcare team is monitoring his ABG values closely. Decreasing the vent rate may further reduce the transpulmonary pressure, which could worsen his respiratory status.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is unclear, and the healthcare team is continuing antibiotics and monitoring for further cultures.
3. Septic/cardiogenic shock: The patient's shock status is being closely monitored, and the healthcare team is maintaining his blood pressure with afterload reduction and vasopressors.
4. Sedation: The patient's sedation level is adequate, but the healthcare team should continue to monitor his level of consciousness and adjust his sedation as needed.
5. Nutrition: The patient's nutrition is being repleted with fiber, but his high residuals yesterday are a concern. The healthcare team should continue to monitor his nutritional intake and adjust as needed.
6. Glycemic control: The patient's glucose levels are being monitored, and regular insulin sliding scale is being used to maintain euglycemia.
7. Lines: The patient has multiple lines in place, including a multi-lumen line and an arterial line, which should be closely monitored for complications.
8. Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP, which should be continued to prevent complications.
9. Code status: The patient's code status is full code, and the healthcare team should continue to monitor his condition closely.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 50-year-old male with metastatic renal cell carcinoma, who has undergone nephrectomy, IL-2 therapy, mini-allograft stem cell transplantation, and donor lymphocyte infusion. He presented to the hospital with hypoxic respiratory failure, fevers, and hypotension.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and on ventilator support with a PCV+ mode, with a tidal volume of 28 cmH2O, respiratory rate of 30, and FiO2 of 100%. The patient has a persistent abnormal interstitial pattern on chest X-ray, which may be due to pulmonary fibrosis.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient's blood pressure has improved, and he is no longer requiring dobutamine. His central venous pressure (CVP) goal is >8 mmHg, which is being met. He has RV hypokinesis and dysfunction, likely due to high intrapulmonary pressures.
* Endocrine status: The patient has a history of adrenalectomy and adrenal gland metastasis. He is receiving IV hydrocortisone taper.
* Metastatic renal cell carcinoma: The patient has recurrent disease after donor lymphocyte infusion.
* Sedation: The patient is currently sedated with midazolam, fentanyl, and methadone, which is being continued for now.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is precarious, and he may require further ventilatory support or consideration of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
* Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to his underlying condition and the presence of a central line and ventilator.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's history of adrenalectomy and adrenal gland metastasis puts him at risk for adrenal insufficiency, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
* Metastatic disease progression: The patient's recurrent disease may continue to progress, which could lead to further complications and decreased quality of life.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation and sedation may increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as aspiration or gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on this information, it is essential to continue monitoring the patient's respiratory, cardiovascular, and endocrine status closely and to adjust his treatment plan accordingly. Further evaluation and management of his metastatic renal cell carcinoma and adrenal insufficiency are also necessary.

   # Respiratory failure:
   Pneumonia as likely source of resp failure and sepsis in patient with
   poor pulmonary reserve due to emphysema, ?GVHD, fibrosis.

   midazolam although methadone was added; oxygenation seems to worsen
   when patient is dysynchronous / less sedated.

   adrenal insufficiency).  CVP goal > 8, and meeting that criteria.  From
   cardiac perspective, RV hypokinesis and dysfunction though to be [**2-3**]
   high intrapulmonary pressures (hypoxia, pulmonary fibrosis).  Now able
   to maintain BP off dobutamine.  Although CI decreased, will cont to
   follow urine output and MAP trend.
